On 14/10/05, Kent Beck <kentb@...> wrote:
>
>  James,
>
> One of the substantial design changes in JUnit 4 is there is no longer a
> Composite hierarchy of tests. The arbitrary depth and ability to create
> custom TestSuites and insert TestDecorators made writing runners
> difficult,
> especially re-run. Instead you now pass a flat array of test classes to
> JUnitCore to run a suite of tests. The RunListener doesn't currently
> provide
> notification when one of those classes starts and stops. I can imagine
> such
> notification might be useful, but I don't want to put it in without more
> justification than that. Can you distill your wishes into a test case?
>
> Sincerely yours,
>
> Kent Beck
> Three Rivers Institute


Kent,

I didn't get the time I anticipated to look at this over the weekend, and
then I realised that two hours probably wasn't long enough to get up to
speed with Java 5 and the version 4 changes. I think your suggestion of
writing a test case would be the quickest way to work out whether this
feature is justifiable in the core implementation or whether I can distill
it into something simpler, so I'll look to do that instead (using JUnit4,
obviously!)

The removal of Composite is interesting. I was using it in my application
thus, along with a custom runner:

   - It is an application for functional testing of multi-channel
   websites; i.e. WML, HTML, XHTML, XHTML MP, etc.
    - For each response which comes back to the client, build up a
   PageTestSuite composed of all the PageTestCase subclasses configured for
   that device (user-agent).
   - Run the PageTestSuite.

I completely understand the problems caused by using Composite here. In my
application, the easiest way to re-run failed tests was to record them in a
particular format into a file and then use that file as the input to running
the application again. I think TestNG uses a similar mechanism.

My initial reasons for wanting this functionality included the fact that I
didn't want to have to walk the object model twice - once as the test runner
operates and then again to build up a representation of how I want the
results to be displayed. I'm not so sure about this now. I think I had too
great an attachment to using Observer for this, which may be correct if you
don't have the entire object model in memory at one point; i.e. some sort of
event based thing would be required. I'm leaning towards the viewpoint that
the representation of the results should just be a View on the results and
should be implemented however I want, which may include walking the object
model twice. The problem that I'm trying to decide on is what should be
provided to help construct this View. Thoughts welcome, along with
suggestions for different Views that you might want?

Regards,

James

> > > The current design provides testRunStarted(int count) and

> > > sufficient for your purposes or do you need to be notified
> > when a class'
> > > tests are about to be run and have finished running?
> > >
> > > Sincerely yours,
> > >
> > > Kent Beck
> > > Three Rivers Institute
> > >
> >
> > Hi Kent,
> >
> > That sounds promising, so I'll pull my finger out and take a
> > more thorough
> > look at the JUnit 4 source and Java 5 stuff this weekend and
> > try to get a
> > feel for it.
> >
> > My use case for JUnit 3 was to be notified when a TestSuite that I had
> > created, rather than an implicit one that JUnit creates for
> > you, was about
> > to start processing and had finished processing. This nicely
> > let me capture
> > a hierarchical view of all the TestSuites that had run. I
> > ended up modifying
> > my TestRunner, since I had constant known case of always
> > having the same
> > level of nesting for my constructed TestSuites.
> >
> > A quick scan of the Version4 branch found the the note in the
> > to-do.txt file
> > about meeting the needs of runner developers! I appreciate
> > that writing a
> > TestRunner like this is a somewhat specialized activity
> > versus everyday use,
> > but was wondering if there has been any provision in JUnit 4
> > for authors of
> > TestRunners - could you provide any more detail about
> > envisaged use cases?
> >
> > James
